headline.main: Breast-Feeding May Not Lead to Leaner Children

headline.print_headline: ‘Anti-Bloomberg Bill’ in Mississippi Bars Local Restrictions on Food and Drink
headline.main: ‘Anti-Bloomberg Bill’ in Mississippi Bars Local Restrictions on Food and Drink

docs.abstract: Mississippi lawmakers pass bill saying any law that might limit what Mississippians eat or drink has to go through them--barring federal regulations; legislation in state with highest rate of obesity in nation is likely to be signed quickly by Gov Phil Bryant.
docs.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers governing the state with the highest rate of obesity in the nation said any law that might limit what Mississippians eat or drink has to go through them — barring federal regulations.
docs.snippet: Lawmakers governing the state with the highest rate of obesity in the nation said any law that might limit what Mississippians eat or drink has to go through them — barring federal regulations.

headline.main: Not So Sweet: Investigating Science and Health Questions About Sugar and Our Bodies

byline.original: By MICHAEL GONCHAR and JENNIFER CUTRARO

docs.abstract: In this lesson, we’ll help students investigate the science and myths about added sugars. How unhealthy are they? What happens to sugar when ingested? And how much sugar do we actually consume?
docs.snippet: In this lesson, we’ll help students investigate the science and myths about added sugars. How unhealthy are they? What happens to sugar when ingested? And how much sugar do we actually consume?

headline.seo: Soda Legal Battle May Outlast Bloomberg’s Tenure
headline.print_headline: Legal Battle Over Limits on Sugary Drinks May Outlast Bloomberg’s Tenure
headline.main: Legal Battle Over Limits on Sugary Drinks May Outlast Mayor’s Tenure

docs.abstract: Case over soda wars is shaping up as landmark of New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg's administration, but timing of legal battle suggests definitive ruling is not likely to come before  Bloomberg leaves office on Dec 31; city lawyers file papers in Manhattan intermediate appeals court and Bloomberg weighs in, saying ruling in his anti-obesity campaign by State Supreme Court Justice Milton A Tingling is 'totally wrong'.
docs.lead_paragraph: A fight seems headed to New York State’s highest court, and a final ruling may not come until next year.
docs.snippet: A fight seems headed to New York State’s highest court, and a final ruling may not come until next year.

docs.abstract: Editorial acknowledges New York State judge's rejection of New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg's ban on servings of sugary drinks larger than 16 ounces was necessary; says ban was ill conceived and poorly constructed; outlines some better ways for Bloomberg and health officials to combat obesity.
docs.lead_paragraph: There are better ways for the mayor to use his time and resources to combat obesity in New York City than to ban giant sugary drinks.
docs.snippet: There are better ways for the mayor to use his time and resources to combat obesity in New York City than to ban giant sugary drinks.

headline.seo: Behind Soda Industry’s Win, a Phalanx of Sponsored Minority Groups
headline.print_headline: Bottlers and Minority Groups, Soda War Allies
headline.main: Minority Groups and Bottlers Team Up in Battles Over Soda

docs.abstract: Dozens of Hispanic and African-American civil rights groups, health advocacy organizations and business associations have joined the beverage industry in opposing soda regulation, arguing that such measures are discriminatory, paternalistic or ineffective; many of these groups are recipients of tens of millions of dollars from the beverage industry that has flowed to nonprofits and educational organizations.
docs.lead_paragraph: Despite high rates of obesity in the populations they work for, groups with a long history of funding by the beverage industry are now fighting measures like New York City’s stalled soda ban.
docs.snippet: Despite high rates of obesity in the populations they work for, groups with a long history of funding by the beverage industry are now fighting measures like New York City’s stalled soda ban.

keywords.value: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
keywords.name: organizations

headline.main: Mixed Reviews For a Judge’s Ruling

docs.abstract: Readers respond to The New York Times article about judge's decision to strike down New York City's impending limits on large sugary drinks. (M)
docs.lead_paragraph:
The New York Times article on a judge’s ruling on Monday striking down the city’s impending limits on large sugary drinks drew more than 1,300 comments from readers representing a wide range of regulatory philosophies. Here are some of them. A few have been condensed slightly. 

 
This is one time when common sense won out. Yes, too much sugar is bad, but the law was dumb. Anyone who wanted more soda could just refill their cup, especially in all those fast-food restaurants with self-service soda machines, which is most of them. The law also created a maze of rules and applied only to specific places serving specific kinds of choices, but not the choice to drink as much soda or have as much sugar as you wanted. — Carmela Sanford, Niagara Falls, N.Y.
docs.snippet: The New York Times article on a judge’s ruling on Monday  striking down the city’s impending limits  on large sugary drinks drew more than 1,300 comments from readers representing a wide range of regulatory philosophies. Here are some...

headline.main: Bloomberg Again Blasts Court Ruling on Large Sugary Drinks

docs.abstract: A day after a judge derailed his planned restrictions, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg forcefully defended them in an appearance at a restaurant whose owner said he was adopting the limits on his own.
docs.snippet: A day after a judge derailed his planned restrictions, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg forcefully defended them in an appearance at a restaurant whose owner said he was adopting the limits on his own.
